questions.text: A newly married couple recently had a baby. The family was visited by a pediatric resident on rounds for a routine checkup on postnatal day 1. He encouraged the mother to breastfeed and told them about a specific hormone which is increased during feeding. This hormone is responsible for milk ejection and is regulated by a positive feedback mechanism. It also stimulates a positive mood in the mother and increases the emotional attachment of mother and child. Therefore also known as the ‘love hormone’. Name the hormone and the most common second messenger involved during its uterotonic action.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxytocin ; ip3-dag pathway The given history points towards Milk ejection Love hormone Positive feedback regulation Positive mood and attachment Therefore the correct option is oxytocin. Now uterotonic action of oxytocin means action which involves contractions, and so the receptors will activate ca+, via the ip3 - dag pathway.

questions.text: Pituitary hormones are mostly regulated by signals from the hypothalamus. One such mechanism is the secretion of inhibiting hormones via tubuloinfundibular pathway. A hormone ‘x’ inhibits reproductive function by suppressing Hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and pituitary Gonadotropin secretion and impairing gonadal steroidogenesis In both women and men. It also acts to induce and maintain lactation, decrease reproductive function, and suppress sexual drive. Identify the hormone for which this mechanism follows in our body.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolactin Prl is unique among the pituitary hormones in that the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory and via tuberoinfundibular pathway. The pituitary hormone which is regulated with inhibiting hormones are TSH PRL GH Now inhibited through tuberoinfundibular pathway = prl ( prolactin) The important line here is = Hormones inhibit gonadotropin-releasing hormone - that must be via negative feedback And inhibit gonadal steroids - so estrogen and testosterone are reduced. So either FSH or LH is increased = decreased GnRH . But then estrogen testosterone should be elevated. Or prolactin is increased which can inhibit GnRH and therefore gonadal steroids. so this problem question points towards prolactin.

Prl levels increase markedly (about tenfold) during pregnancy and decline rapidly within 2 weeks of parturition. If breastfeeding is initiated, basal prl levels remain elevated; suckling stimulates transient reflex increases in prl levels that last for about 30–45 min .

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented at the emergency room (er), referred by an ophthalmologist, with a 2-year history of frontal headaches and visual disturbances. The patient had no history of head trauma and denied other neurological symptoms. Cerebral MRI revealed a large invasive pituitary mass. Laboratory evaluation revealed a very high prolactin level of 158 700 µu/ml (reference range 58–254). The patient was diagnosed with prolactinoma. The consultant told his students that prolactinoma generally produces its effect in 3 different ways- 1st is by the hormone itself: increase or decrease of it 2nd is known as the ‘stalk effect’ 3rd is the mass effect: compression of structures surrounding the pituitary like optic chiasma. What is the most appropriate conventional hypothesis of the ‘stalk effect’?

options.label: A
options.text: Stalk of the pituitary has glands secreting dopamine, which gets inhibited due to mechanical compression, causing increased prolactin

options.label: B
options.text: Stalk of the pituitary has lactotroph cells which get stimulated mechanically and lead to increased prolactin

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical interruption of the portal transport (via stalk) of dopamine from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland will reduce inhibition and thus result in minor elevation of prolactin

options.label: D
options.text: Stalk of the pituitary is compressed, which decreases blood supply to the pituitary and therefore decreases prl production

questions.correct_answer: C. Mechanical interruption of the portal transport (via stalk) of dopamine from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland will reduce inhibition and thus result in minor elevation of prolactin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mechanical interruption of the portal transport (via stalk) of dopamine from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland will reduce inhibition and thus result in minor elevation of prolactin. The pars tuberalis is a distinct subdivision of the pituitary gland but its function remains poorlyunderstood. Suprasellar tumors in this pars tuberalis region are frequently accompanied by hyperprolactinemia. It has been postulated conventionally that these suprasellar tumors induce hyperprolactinemia by compressing the pituitary stalk, resulting in impaired dopamine delivery to the pituitary and, consequently, disinhibition of the lactotropes An alternative hypothesis proposed is that suprasellar tumors secrete a specific pars tuberalis factor that stimulates prolactin secretion. Hypothesized candidates are the preprotachykinin a derived tachykinins, substance p and/or neurokinin a.
